Award.AwardTitle: Characterization of Pollen Tube Repulsion in Arabidopsis thaliana
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Ravishankar Palanivelu
Proposal #: 0723421
Characterization of pollen tube repulsion in Arabidopsis thaliana

Cell-cell interactions are important during development of all eukaryotic organisms. One particularly unique example involves interactions between a migrating cell and those that are in its path. Avoiding inappropriate interactions is essential for a navigating cell to reach its intended target. In humans, disruption in this process results in polyspermy and neuronal defects. In plants, cell avoidance is exceptionally important during reproduction when pollen tubes avoid egg-bearing ovule structures that have already been fertilized. However, since pollen tube repulsion occurs within opaque floral structures, the dynamic nature of these interactions and the signals that mediate them remain poorly characterized. Recently, a simple biological assay was developed to directly observe pollen tube-ovule interactions. This assay revealed that a short-range repulsion signaling is initiated from an ovule soon after a pollen tube enters it. Capitalizing on this finding, a variety of cell biological, molecular, genetic, biochemical and computational approaches are proposed to conduct a thorough characterization of pollen tube repulsion in the model plant, Arabidopsis thaliana. Insights gained on avoidance of spurious fertilization events could ultimately help in developing genetically modified pollen that cannot fertilize native species, which is an impediment breeders must overcome while developing transgenic crop varieties. This study will generate novel image analysis algorithms that will benefit other migratory cell models such as neurons and dictyostelium, and an open-access educational website on plant reproduction that can be freely used by educators, students, and the public. Biology faculty from Pima Community College, a non-Ph.D. granting institution, and undergraduates, especially those from under represented Native American, African-American and Hispanic communities, will carry out parts of this project. Exposure to biology and hands-on training in research will motivate them to choose a career in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The seeds we depend on for our food are products of double fertilization. This essential process in plant reproduction requires delivery of sperm cells by the pollen tube to the egg and central cells of the embryo sac (female gametophyte). Although double fertilization was discovered more than a century ago, the controlling molecular mechanisms and genes remain poorly understood.

    The goal of the awarded proposal (in 2007) is to characterize pollen tube repulsion (an essential prior to double fertilization) in Arabidopsis.  Specifically, we proposed to (1) perform a thorough characterization of pollen tube repulsion and unravel the basic aspects of this previously uncharacterized signaling process and to develop an image analysis system that will quantify pollen tube repulsion in an automated and high-throughput manner, (2) use ref1 mutant–defective in pollen tube repulsion–to clone and identify a gene involved in pollen tube repulsion signaling and (3) develop an in vitro pollen tube repulsion assay and characterize the properties of pollen tube repulsion activity. All of the goals proposed in the awarded grant have been accomplished and the salient findings are summarized below.

Aim 1: We established the temporal and spatial relationship between pollen tube repulsion and other processes during pollen tube-ovule interactions for the first time in Arabidopsis and identified small molecules in ovules (manuscripts in preparation). We developed a robust approach for automated tracking of multiple pollen tubes that exhibit random growth and interact with ovules in vitro to aid in our analysis of pollen tube repulsion and reception. Such a tracking capability is novel and facilitates high throughput image analysis. We note that standard approaches and existing commercial software cannot achieve adequate performance on this kind of data (Brau et al 2011).

Aim 2: We used the mutant isolated in our lab to clone the LORELEI (LRE) gene and made the discovery LRE plays a critical role in mediating the arrest of pollen tube growth in the female gametophyte prior to sperm release. In addition, we discovered that LRE also has a role in double fertilization and early seed development. These findings have been published as two research articles (Tsukamoto et al 2010 and Tsukamoto and Palanivelu 2010).

Aim 3: We developed a novel, microfluidics-based, pollen tube guidance assay to overcome difficulties in analyzing Arabidopsis pollen tube responses to the microgradient of guidance cues and published these findings (Copper et al 2009 and Yetisen et al 2011).

In addition to these findings, we also identified several new mutants that suppress the defects in lre mutant and discovered several genes that are uniquely expressed in female reproductive tissues. In summary, the award provided complete or partial support for 10 publications and 1 undergraduate honors thesis.

This project also had high impact on human resources. It promoted synergistic interactions among scientists from biology and computer science and involved biology faculty from Pima community college, a non-Ph.D. granting institution. Undergraduates, especially those from under represented Native American, African-Americans and Hispanic community, carried out parts of this project. University of Arizona and Pima community college student populations provided unique opportunities to recruit students from these underrepresented groups. Exposure to biology and hands on training in research motivated them to choose a career in science. In total, this project provided training for one male and one female postdoctoral fellow, one male graduate student, two female research technicians, nine undergraduate students (5 female and 4 male) and six high school students (4 female and 2 male).
